title.narrative: Advancing Gender Equality through Economic and Social Empowerment, and Protection Services targeting Women and Girls. Annual report (1 November 2018 to 31 December 2020)

description.narrative: The project aim to benefit 500 households from vulnerable communities in Amman ,Aqaba, and Zarqa. The direct beneficiaries are estimated to be 65% females and 35% males. The total estimated number of beneficiaries from all household engaged with this program activities( livelihood, trainings, women empowerment, and peter parenting, case managment, child center activities, youth activities and psychosocial support) is estimated to be 2400.

activity-date.narrative: This is project start date, but the activities started after we obtaining approval form ministry of planning

recipient-country.narrative: Using a holistic approach to development through case management, our targets are family units instead of individuals. As such, the project will benefit both female and male, recognizing the gender variances in the family social structure and tailoring specific services to empower each gender and age group accordingly. 500 adult females and males will benefit from access to livelihood component with a 60% female and 40% male distribution. These participants and other adults of both genders in the family will also benefit from knowledge and information, and Better Parenting components. Children, adolescents and youth of both genders will benefit from improved family environment promoting education opportunities, technical, vocational, and life skills training, and recreational and leadership activities. All age segments in the family will also benefit from increased resilience of all family members.

sector.narrative: The project aims to address the interlinked nature of livelihood and protection threats by empowering women economically to become part of the workforce, and by addressing cases of GBV and domestic violence. JRF’s innovative approach focuses on achieving a lasting positive trickle-down effect on families and communities at large; by addressing each family as a functional healthy family unit – merging both livelihood and family protection tracks. Using JRF’s holistic approach, the project aspires to help vulnerable families improve resilience and achieve self-reliance through: • Access to livelihoods: Improve access to practical skills and gainful employment; this is managed through JRF’s Community Empowerment Program (CEP), offering two tracks: generation/expansion of micro and small enterprises, and job placement in private sector organizations. • Child safety and family protection: Identify at-risk children, including those engaged in child labor and victims of sexual and gender-based violence (SGBV), such as early marriage, and increase access to preventative and protective case management interventions. The project also aims to build and reinforce a healthy and functional family unit and home environment to ensure child safety through the provision of effective women empowerment and parenting sessions. This will be managed through local family protection units with a family advisor assigned to oversee progress within each family.

title.narrative: Market Assessment

description.narrative: A market assessment was conducted to identify and assess market opportunities and gaps through an in-depth market assessment of the value-chain within the targeted areas. A triangulation assessment technique was implemented adopting both quantitative and qualitative assessment methodologies, through structured questionnaires, Focus Group Discussions, and individual interviews. Furthermore, the assessment will include Key Informant Interviews with relevant key stakeholders and entities, to ensure an in-depth understanding and comprehensive mapping exercise

title.narrative: Market Assessment Report Report was released internally

description.narrative: JRF training and consultancy division have developed and tailored specific assessment tools in order to achieve the outcomes below:  Identifying the micro-business understating and most common trends in the areas.  Understanding the labor market and work-force in the areas.  Investigate areas of intervention and local community understanding of child protection and domestic violence  Understanding the soft-skills required in individuals enrolling in Micro-business stream or work force in order to develop and tailor the training content accordingly. the assessment revolved around seeking answers for the below mentioned questions: Community mapping: 1. What is the level of unemployment among the randomly selected assessment sample, and those looking for work? 2. What are the individual skills of the target population? 3. What is the extent of reliance on casual (temporary) versus formal work within the households in the target areas? 4. What are the protection related needs in the target areas? 5. What are the current levels of access to and needs for access to protection information and services, in the target community? And What are the main protection concerns in the community, and how are households or individuals currently coping with these shocks? Micro - business: 1. What are the current predominant enterprises of Syrian refugees and Jordanians living in the target areas? • What are the main skills requirements? • What are the potential areas of business (business ideas) for the target population? • What skills are required to run the enterprises successfully? Work – Force: 1. What are the market sectors that have the biggest demand of job opportunities (sectors and sub-sectors)? 2. What are the barriers and incentives for the available job opportunities disaggregated by sub-sectors? 3. What are the accessible locations where the targeted population accept and are willing to travel to for work (economic catchment zones)? Do they have the propensity to broader economic mobility

title.narrative: Aflatoun: Child Social and Financial Empowerment” Program

description.narrative: Aflatoun program that aimed to enhance the child's knowledge and skills in topics related to self-awareness, social and financial literacy, living values and citizenship

title.narrative: Number of children a engaged in social and financial empowerment program through “Aflatoun” program

description.narrative: Aflatoun program engaged the children with activities that teaches them about their roles and responsibilities within the family and community, personal hygiene, saving money and planning for simple personal projects, volunteering and serving the community, as well as taking initiatives. It infuses communication through reading, playing, conversing, writing and expressing through various forms of art and play

title.narrative: Adolescents clubs conducted by Youth committees

description.narrative: Each Youth Committee led by a Social Worker conducted Adolescents club in three location

title.narrative: Number of adolescents engaged in the adolescent clubs created by the YCs in three location

description.narrative: Each club hosted per year 211 adolescents in Amman, 121 adolescents in Aqaba, and 158 adolescents in Zarqa. Boys and girls grouped separately. The clubs specifically for adolescent boys and girls, especially those at risk of child labour, SGBV and Early Marriage. Through these clubs the project provided a safe place for children to play, learn financial and social skills, and emotional wellbeing. The activities were mostly customized to the preference of adolescents in the area.

title.narrative: Microbusiness mentoring

description.narrative: JRF developed a structured two level mentoring system designed to meet the needs of MSE beneficiaries. The system consist of : 1- Specialized Technical Mentors 2-JRF Expert Business Mentors

title.narrative: Number of mentors chosen to provide technical guidance and expertise for micro-business beneficiaries

description.narrative: Mentors provided technical guidance and expertise in different subject areas. These mentors trained for two days of coaching and mentorship. An average of 75 mentors was chosen through vocational training centers, to participate in this project. Their role included, (a) conducting a one visit per month to beneficiaries, (b) offering technical and business support to those beneficiaries each in their respective sectors and (c) allowing for the exchange of knowledge to enhance perspectives Mentors provided technical guidance and expertise in different subject areas. These are successful local practitioners who possess years of experience in different fields. . These mentors trained for two days of coaching and mentorship.

title.narrative: Microbusiness established through livelihood grants

description.narrative: JRF encouraged entrepreneurs, in terms of skills and business ideas, to become partners and form successful businesses. This group of beneficiaries was guided based on the findings of the market assessment, to support them with successful business opportunities. A committee from JRF were overseen eligible business ideas and accordingly they decided those that benefit from the seed capital offered through this project.

title.narrative: Entrepreneurs received grants to start their own micro-businesses

description.narrative: A total of 300 Microbusinesses supported During the project. Below are the categories to which the Microbusinesses has been distributed: *Governorate: 30% Amman , 56% Zarqa ,14% Aqaba. * sectors: 35% productive ,46% services ,1% agriculture ,14% construction ,4% commercial. * Gender : 33% Male , 67% Female. *Nationality: 82% Jordanian , 18% Syrian

title.narrative: Employment Facilitation and Career Advisory

description.narrative: JRF offered follow-up and monitoring services to the 100 beneficiaries and offered a career planning, advisory and consultation services to beneficiaries, starting from the interview process and at their workplace.

title.narrative: Technical guidance and expertise for Employment Beneficiaries

description.narrative: JRF supported the beneficiaries in the preparation of CVs, Three follow-up visits were conducted for each beneficiary at their workplace to identify challenges and support beneficiaries through managing of expectations, providing advice and guidance, and enabling channels of feedback, as appropriate, to and from employers.

title.narrative: Case Management and Psychological Counselling

description.narrative: JRF provided case management and psychosocial support in a timely, confidential, and appropriate manner to households of the project (women, children, adolescents and youth)

title.narrative: Number of cases identified through the case-management to be provided with different protection services

description.narrative: The psychosocial counselling aimed to improve the well-being of women and children who are in need of in depth counselling, especially cases of SGBV. The different methodologies used by women allowed them to choose their preferred type of service, as well as help them address multiple needs. Case management and psychological counselling were also provided to children, particularly those who are involved in or are at risk of child labour and SGBV, and their families in a timely, child-friendly, confidential, and appropriate manner

title.narrative: CBO selection in Zarqa

description.narrative: Khawla Bint AlAzwar CBO in Zarqa based on specific criteria developed by JRF M&E team was selected. To ensure successful implementation of activities, JRF built the capacities of the CBO through a 5 - day Institutional Strengthening Training Program. its main purpose is elevating the capacities of the CBOs through exposing them to financial, organizational, managerial, procurement, and grants management training. JRF will support the partner CBO in Zarqa to function as a Family and Child Protection Center

title.narrative: CBO capacity building and SOP training

description.narrative: 5 members of the CBO staff received the capacity building training.the training aim to elevate the capacities of the CBOs through exposing them to financial, organizational, managerial, procurement, and grants management training.SOP training; to ensure the quality of provided services to beneficiaries a 3 days training on following the standard procedures at JRF was given to the 3 teams in the 3 targeted governorates. Followed by a technical training on case management for the project 3 case managers, where they received 12 days of technical training.

title.narrative: Raising the awareness of children about all types of abuse through engaging them in active learning (My little home simulator)

description.narrative: My Little Home (MLH) is a simulator of a simple home located within QRFCC and QRCEC premises. It contains different corners which include a kitchen, bathroom, bedroom, living room, a special room, garden, a road and the local shops. It aims to enhance the knowledge and skills of children and parents on topics of child protection through hands on activities, especially designed and customized to fit into the simulator’s different corners

title.narrative: Number of children and parents in three location, engaged in awareness raising activities through my little home simulator

comment.narrative: Throughout the MLH experience, the children were engaged through games that teach children the meaning of emotions, how to be safe, and how to engage in exciting cost-free activities. It also offered adults simple techniques to provide an engaging, healthy and safe home environment through utilizing what is available around them at no or low cost. MLH addressed concepts of child protection through a unique structured approach led by JRF experts. it targeted 785 Jordanians and Syrian children.

title.narrative: Empowerment and parenting education sessions

description.narrative: The 15 PEC members reached a total of 1800 beneficiaries (including parents of the 500 households, and other community members) through conducted 90 empowerment and parenting education sessions

title.narrative: Number of parenting education training sessions facilitated by the PEC in the three location

description.narrative: The parent education committees were conducted 90 awareness sessions in three locations, the sessions focused on the below subject: 1-Self - affirmation 2- Developmental characteristics of children 3- Early marriage 5- Types of violence and indicators of abuse

title.narrative: Establish a Steering Committee

description.narrative: The Steering committee was monitoring the activities that were implemented by the project team in the CBO.

title.narrative: The CBO steering committee was established to oversee the overall implementation activities at the CBO location.

description.narrative: The committee was making sure that the activities were carried out with the required quality in addition to providing technical and administrative guidanceto the project team in the CBO, Through the periodic meetings held by the steering committee in the CBO.

title.narrative: Capacity building of livilehood beneficaries target beneficiaries

description.narrative: The capacity building program of livilehood beneficaries consist of two parts; i. Foundation Value Driven Training. ii. Micro and Small Enterprises Track. iii. Job Placement Training.

title.narrative: 30 groups with total of 718 beneficiaries received the Foundation Value Driven Training, and 12 groups with total of 321 beneficiaries received the advanced Micro and Small Enterprises Track training. 11 groups with total of 264 beneficiaries received the Preparing beneficiaries to enter the labor market and employment training
Community Based meetings

description.narrative: The community based meetings/information sessions is a key tool in raising awareness and buy-in of the project objectives, approach, target groups, eligibility and selection criteria, as well as to encourage community members to apply

title.narrative: 31 info sessions were conducted in the 3 targeted areas, 3069 attendees.

description.narrative: 31 info sessions instead of 8 were conducted in the 3 targeted areas; to expand the in-depth outreach to the most vulnerable households to participate in the project. with average of 75 attendees per session instead of 150. The session is followed by one-to-one interview, 505 household were selected based on criteria developed by JRF through several processes including socio-economic profiling questionnaires, interviews, and the tailored selection criteria

title.narrative: Forming and training the Parent education committees ( PEC) in three location Amman, Aqaba and Zarqa

description.narrative: Theses committees was to support the implementation of key response and prevention activities

title.narrative: Number of PECs formed by Number of parents educators in Amman, Aqaba and Zarqa

description.narrative: 2.3 ToT on Empowerment and Parenting Skills Through 4 training days, participants enrolled in this program have obtained informative knowledge related to parenting and empowerment topics, generally; the training covered the below mentioned topics: - Self-assertion and the developmental characteristics for children. -Violence, Child Marriage and Child Labor. -Facilitation Skills. -Practical Practices in parental care The training aimed to obtain the general objective to empower a pool of local community educators with facilitation skills enabling them to implement awareness sessions within the local community in topics related to parenting skills. During the 4th and last training day it was dedicated to participants demonstrating and practicing an awareness session, 20 minutes were allocated for each participant and a constructive feedback group session had been implemented afterwards, to assure strength points and allow corrective actions. Towards the end of the training, the below objectives had been achieved: -Participants were able to build a clear vision of concepts related to self-assertion, violence, child labor, early marriage, facilitation and training. -Participants gained self-assertion skills and how to implement self-assertion steps, in addition to distinguishing self-asserting responses from unconfirmed responses to oneself. -Participants were able to recognize the developmental characteristics of children and to apply the best parental practices required for each developmental stage to enhance child development and prevent abuse. -Participants were able to apply the required facilitation skills in education sessions, in addition to the process of preparation and preparation, and the application of the elements of the training workshop. Participants demonstrated an ability to choose an appropriate training method for parenting issues. - Facilitation skills, methods, and elements of the training workshop received the largest share of participants' discussions. Therefore, each participant was applied so that during the practical application the appropriate skills, methods, and basic elements of facilitation sessions. -Participants showed a clear interest in forms of abuse and early warning signs, so video and case studies were presented, discussions were held on case studies, and a review of participants' ability to classify cases and distinguish warning signs. Where the participants showed good abilities. -Participants were able to build a clear vision of the concept of early marriage and child labor, distinguishing the group most affected by early marriage, and knowing the effects of early marriage and child labor, and the participants got acquainted with the support aspects of upcoming early marriage cases on marriage or cases that became early marriage and cases of child labor

title.narrative: Employment and Job matching mentoring

description.narrative: Through this activity, beneficiaries have been networked with appropriate job opportunities based on the skills and knowledge they possess, and after they have been involved in a training program to prepare them for entry to the labor market

title.narrative: Number of beneficiaries placed to job opportunities

description.narrative: After JRF identified potential employers and market needs through the Market Assessment completed, JRF facilitated a job matching sessions between the beneficiaries and respective employers. JRF facilitated interview and employment process between the candidates and the potential employers. 100 beneficiaries were hired in Amman and Zarqa.

title.narrative: Forming and training Youth committee(YC) in three location Amman, Zarqa and Aqaba

description.narrative: Youth committees consisting of 5 Syrian and Jordanian youth in each location (total 15 YCs), . They supported to carry out specific activities, particularly the engagement of children, adolescents, and youth in different activities, such as setting up adolescents’ clubs for children aged 12 – 16, raising awareness of children about all types of abuse though engaging them in active learning

title.narrative: Number of PECs members trained on ToT on empowerment and parenting education

description.narrative: The training was aimed to build local community youth capacities and provide them with skills to utilize in the awareness sessions targeting adolescents. The training achieveed the below outcomes: -Raising the competencies of individuals in facilitation and communication skills to implement training sessions. - Employing effective communication skills to implement training sessions. -Building a clear vision about presentation and presentation skills. -Implementing training sessions and provide feedback to the participants. During the implementation of the training various and interactive activities, the below topics had been covered -Self-awareness and appreciation. -Communication and leadership skills - Facilitation, monitoring and evaluation skills -practical practices
